resources.string: Search for or look-up a Bukusu word to view its definition in English
Word not found. Recheck spelling or look-up instead.

The Bukusu-English dictionary is an Android app to lookup English definitions of Bukusu words. It is intended to serve as an aid to language learners who know English but who seek to improve their knowlege of the Bukusu language. At least a rudimentary grasp of Bukusu is assumed.

" The Bukusu-English Dictionary app is largely based on the draft of the 'Bukusu-English Dictionary' compiled and edited by Michael Marlo, Adrian Sifuna, Aggrey Wasike (2008).
Efforts are underway to expand upon this base and further contributions by Bukusu language experts and native speakers are encouraged. (Kindly tap on the 'Contact Us' link in the 'Help & Settings' menu to get in touch with the app developers in this regard.)"

" The current version of the application allows a user to search for a word from the search box within the action bar at the top of the screen.
Suggestions corresponding to the current search term appear as a scrollable drop-down list with individually clickable/selectable words.
It is also possible to lookup a specific word on the alphabetically ordered list of all available words in the 'LOOKUP' tab on the main application screen.
Upon performing a successful search or lookup, the definition of the required word is displayed on the 'DEFINITION' tab.
Searching for words not contained in the dictionary will result in a message communicating an unsuccessful search being displayed on the main screen."

" The words are primarily displayed and searchable in the Bukusu orthography in common use. Also included are the transcriptions from the original source complete with tone marking in which:
long vowels are marked as a sequence of two vowels, e.g.,[aa],
a syllable boundary between two vowels is marked by '.',
high-tone is marked with an acute accent,
low-tone is unmarked,
'b' represents [b] after a nasal and [β] elsewhere,
'ch' represents [č],
'sh' represents [š],
'kh' represents [x],
'ng'' ('ng' followed by an apostrophe) represents [ŋ],
'nj' represents [ñǰ], and 'ng' represents [ŋg].
In general, 'ny' should represent the palatal nasal [ñ], although there may be cases where the same orthographic sequence represents the sequence of a coronal nasal followed by a palatal glide, i.e., [ny]."

" The following abbreviations are used to mark parts of speech:
'adj' - adjective 'adv' - adverb 'comp' - complement 'conj' - conjunction 'dem' - demonstrative 'excl' - exclamation 'ideo' - ideophone 'loc' - locative 'n' - noun 'neg' - negation element 'np' - noun phrase 'num' - numeral 'poss' - possessive pronoun 'pp' - prepositional phrase 'prep' - preposition 'pron' - pronoun 'quan' - quantifier 'relcl' - relative clause 's' - sentence 'v' - verb 'vint' - intransitive verb 'vrefl' - reflexivized verb 'vpass' - passivized verb 'vtr' - transitive verb 'vp' - verb phrase 'wh' - wh- (question) element"
" On the settings menu the user is able to adjust the app theme between the normal mode (light) and the dark mode as per their preference."

" The Bukusu-English Dictionary app is the result of volunteer effort.
As such, the team responsible for developing this app is constantly looking for collaborators and contributors to help make the dictionary better.
Kindly tap on the 'Contact Us' link in the 'Help & Settings' menu to get in touch with the app developers and contribute new words, alternate definitions and usage examples."
